Did you regard the roadblock and the killing of a few people there as a revolution against the government?
I believe that if there had been groups such as our committing this kind of an act on a nationwide scale, it would have caused large scale chaos.  We were not the only ones who were acting.
Why did you not remain there at the scene and continue to kill as many black people as possible and create chaos?
As I have stated, we held a torch over the people and it appeared as if they were all dead.
But that's what you went there for, to do and kill isn't it?  What was surprising about that?  Wasn't that the precise purpose?
Everybody appeared to be dead to me and I didn't know what else to do on the scene.  They were all lying very still and it appeared as if they were all dead.
You regarded that as part of the revolution?
Now why did you not continue the revolution and kill as many as possible if you regarded what you did as part of the revolution?

Chairperson, the following day at Japie Oelofse's we decided to lay low.  He didn't give us a reason therefore but I assumed that it was because he realised that his people hadn't acted the way he thought they would.  He even issued an order telling me to get rid of the Mercedes and that is why we stopped the whole story at that point, the revolution that is.

I'm trying to understand your behaviour as a group that night.  You went out to go and kill people, in fact you wanted to attack the squatter camp to kill people, there would have been many people to kill there.
	You went to put up the roadblock to kill people in pursuit of a revolution, now you only kill four or five and then you leave the place and you are not continuing with the killing as planned.  If that was a plan I fail to understand your behaviour.

Chairperson, we identified the enemy as the ANC and we attacked them and after that we left.  If we had acted further, visited squatter camps and so forth, we would have to identify further targets.  Our objective was to attack the ANC/SACP Alliance and those who appeared before us that night were members of the ANC/SACP Alliance.
You were at a point where you were able to find a few of the kind of people you wanted to kill and then you killed them, why not continue to kill more if that was the plan?

If we consider the timing, it was also quite late and we believed that every group countrywide would be acting in the way that we were acting and if that had happened it would have created large scale chaos and it would have promoted the revolution.
Isn't it correct that you people ran away when you thought there was a vehicle coming?
No, I wouldn't say that they ran away, they climbed in the vehicle and drove away but they didn't run away as such.
The fact is, you decided to leave the scene because there was a vehicle coming.
Some of the people left the scene, I didn't leave the scene.
You didn't remain there, you also left.
I left after we had set the vehicles alight and that was quite some time after.
Where were the vehicles set alight?
In order to disguise any clues.
Why worry about things of that nature if the following day you shall have taken over the country?  Why worry about such trivialities when you are busy with something huge, a revolution?

As I have mentioned earlier, we would not want to be identified as the Randfontein Commando and if we had left any traces on the scene, they would have detected us and that is why we left the scene and set the vehicles alight.

Yes, is it not so that you people left the scene because - I mean, when you saw the other vehicle coming, because you were worried you might be arrested?  And isn't the reason why you removed the cartridges, burn the car, was to avoid being arrested by the South African Police who would the following day still be very much in power and control?

Where we were standing it was difficult to see a vehicle approaching from afar, so the vehicle was rather close to us at that point.  While we were busy on the scene - I'm not referring to the group which had already left, a vehicle was approaching and I agree with you that the police would definitely still have been in power the next day and that is why we had to collect all the shells.
At that stage, did you really think that you were busy with a revolution to take over the country?
Definitely.  I believed that such incidents were occurring on a nationwide level.
Did you say that you did not see the child and women or did you say you don't remember whether you saw the child and/or the women?
I can't remember that I saw the women and children.
How can you manage not to remember whether a small child was there, under those circumstances?
The child who was shot was quite grown, it appeared to me to be a grown person.  The other little children who were present I did not see.

Well, while I'm looking to try to find out as to what his age was, the nature of the injuries inflicted on the child were such that it is difficult to accept, it would be difficult to accept that he was hit by accident, half his head was blown away, isn't that so?

Yes, I saw the photo's, that is correct.  As I heard he had been sitting on his mother's lap.  It's very difficult for me to explain, however he was caught in the cross-fire and that is why he was shot.
Doesn't that show that quite possibly intensive fire was inflicted on him?
No, as far as I know we fired in a general direction, we formed a line and we fired.
...[inaudible] the child was harassed and assaulted before he was killed, did you not see that?
Would that have bothered you, to see a child of that age harassed and assaulted?

At that point we were involved in a war and it didn't bother me at all at that point, only much later can I admit that I do have deep sympathy for the family but at that point in time it would not have bothered me.

The Judge remarks in his Judgement that these people were questioned and some of the white people who were there, that is amongst you, said that these black people: "respekteer nie die base nie", and that was also a source of irritation to you people.
Nothing of that sort happened.  It wasn't about who was the boss and who wasn't, it was about finding out to which group these people belonged.
What precisely were you told to do about people who belonged to the ANC, at the roadblock?  What orders were you given in that regard?
We formed the group and decided that we would regard these people as the target and undertake our instructions.
I'm asking about a possible order that could have been conveyed to you from, as you say, General Oelofse?
General Oelofse told us to look for ANC/SACP people as targets, those were his instructions and furthermore we had to kill such people.

Excuse me Chairperson.
	You said that General Oelofse said to: "us", you choice that specific word, why are you choosing that word because you testified earlier that you weren't present and that you'd heard it from Kloppers?
I beg your pardon I will correct myself and then say Kloppers.
You told us that you were advised to get rid of the Mercedes Benze but you didn't want to do that, why?

I believed firmly that the revolution was definitely breaking out and we believed that Eugene Terreblanche would make his declaration of war on the 16th but it did not happen and I realised myself that it was simply too late because the Mercedes had been seen on the scene of the offence and everybody knew that I drove a big Mercedes, it would have been pointless to get rid of it.
You seem no to be having more than one reason for not getting rid of the Mercedes, because earlier on I thought that your explanation was that you thought that the revolution was on anyway.

Now, I don't understand why you would still have been under that impression when it must have been clear to you the very following day that you must have realised that other AWB regions did not on the previous night do what you people had been doing.

I waited and believed until the 16th of December which was three days away, that something would happen and for that reason I did not conceal my Mercedes.  After the media reports appeared and mentioned the Mercedes which had been driving in the direction of Randfontein, I realised that it would be pointless to try to conceal the Mercedes.
And you say another reason was, at any rate people had noticed or come to know that there was a Mercedes Benze and they probably would know that it was yours.
You said one of the objectives was to search for illegal weapons?
And if you found then you would take them away?
What about legitimately possessed weapons?  If you had found that one of the people you stopped had a firearm for which he had a license, that you would not remove?
I can't answer that question because it didn't happen.  Our instruction was to look for unlawful firearms and that is what we looked for.

Well, you would not have gone against the order would you because the order said: "Remove illegally possessed weapons, so if you had to follow the order it would mean that the weapons legally possessed would not be removed?
That is how I understood the instruction.
And then you put up a roadblock, you are in the middle of a revolution, somebody comes with a weapon lawfully possessed, you let him go with the weapon?
As I've said, I can't answer that because it did not occur.
I just want to clear something with you, when I raised the question of the child you said something like, I thought you tried to estimate to us as to how big the child was or am I mistaken?
Did you not a few minutes ago try to indicate to me that it was not such a small child and try to indicate how big the child could have been?
Does he come into the picture, does that mean you are no able to recall the child and you now see the child in your mind?
I can remember one thing and that is that he appeared to me to be a young man rather than a child.
Is that the one who was seated on the mother's lap?   I beg your pardon.  You've referred to a child at a later stage, that the child was seated on the mother's lap.
That is what I found out afterwards, I can't answer to that.
Are you saying that in your view this child or however you describe him, are you saying that he was a legitimate target?
When we listened to Eugene Terreblanche's social speeches, the child was definitely a target.
When you people decided to go and put up a roadblock, was it planned as to how this revolution would be carried out?
I don't know, the information was not conveyed to me by Phil Kloppers.
Were you told how long your operation was going to last?
Were you told what time it should start?
All that was said was that it would occur on that evening and we therefore acted on that evening.
Was it planned as to what should happen the following day?
No, we didn't discuss any further plans before the time, we simply decided about the roadblock and executed it.
As a policeman and possibly also somebody who was an officer in the AWB, don't you thing that when people go on a military operation they plan properly?

The planning which was conveyed to me was based upon information which the General gave to Kloppers regarding the roadblock.  Apparently a similar roadblock had been held before and he was aware of the fact that we had the equipment to undertake a similar operation and it was from there that we executed this operation.

In your view you were going to kill people, what did you as an individual Mr Martin, what was planned for example as to what to do with the bodies of the hundreds, perhaps thousands of people that were going to be killed?
Chairperson, I believed that it would create the fear among the general public to not participate in the elections and that the revolution would initiate there.

Now, what was to happen to the bodies, the dead bodies?  What was the plan?  You were going to kill so many people, what was the plan?  What plan was there as to how or what to do with those bodies of the many people you were going to kill?
According to my instructions the corpses would simply remain there countrywide.  There would be corpses and the corpses would remain there in order to create that fear.

But you said: "according to the instructions", were those the instructions that you received, that the corpses of all the people who would be killed had to be left there or was that simply what you thought?
Please, then you must not tell us that that was an instruction because then I'm going to ask you who issued the instruction and then the situation will become rather problematic.

I beg your pardon Chairperson, before Advocate van der Walt proceeds I have two questions in follow-up.  Firstly you've said that during the questioning you couldn't determine who were men and who were women and who were children, that it was very dark.
Well, I can't remember if everybody was questioned.
That's not my point.  You undertook the questioning?
But you couldn't really distinguish between men, women and children?
It was dark, I couldn't see it.
But you did have a torch?
Where did you find the torch to ensure afterwards that everybody was dead?
Couldn't you use it during questioning?
I didn't use the torch at that point.
The torch wasn't used when you stopped the cars?
Yes, it was used when we stopped the cars.

Very well, and then you've said that you took the road back to Ventersdorp to identify vehicles with black passengers, that you would turn around, take over, issue the signal and stop them at the roadblock, that was the modus operandi.  In the dead of night you would take over a car, you'd be driving in opposite directions, the lights of both vehicles would be on but you'd be able to see who were black passengers and who weren't?
Well, when one drove past one would clearly be able to distinguish.

Very well.  The issue of the ear, I'd like to follow up this issue, what happened to the ear after it had been presented to Phil Kloppers?  You placed it in a plastic bag, gave it to him and placed it in the Mercedes.
I assumed that he had given it to General Oelofse and that this would be confirmed.
When did you find out from Mr Kloppers?
He said it to me himself on that evening, that this was the ear for General Oelofse.
No, the question is, you have said that the ear had been given to General Oelofse, that that had been executed.
And that Kloppers had confirmed with you that he had done this.
When did he confirm this to you on the following day?
During the day we gathered and we went to General Oelofse's small holding.  He told us to cut our hair short and he told me how he had been horrified by the ear which he had received.
So therefore you had seen him before you and Kloppers had visited him again the next day?  Did you report any information?
I'm not asking whether you believe it, I want to know whether you had information.
When did he tell you this?
When we gathered on that day.
Why did you go to Oelofse again on that afternoon after having reported to him?
We were often at Oelofse's small holding.  We went there for the purpose of meeting as we always did, to find out what would happen next and he told us to conceal the Mercedes and so forth.
You described it earlier as an order, wasn't that advice, to get rid of the Mercedes?
He did not say it to me on one occasion only, on quite a number of occasions. I suppose one could have considered it as an order.
No, when I say to you that it was an order, did you understand it as an order, to get rid of the Mercedes?
Why didn't you do it because you had carried out all instructions?
It was pointless to me to conceal the Mercedes.
Therefore, regarding the order to apprehend ANC/SACP supporters, to identify such supporters and to kill such supporters was an order which you obeyed which you could not ignore.

But you received an order to get rid of the Mercedes, something which is quite smaller and you didn't carry it out, but a much greater order to kill people you carried out because of the strength of the order?
As I have already stated it seemed pointless to me to get rid of the Mercedes at that point.
When we received the orders to kill people we were busy with the revolution according to Kloppers.
And you carried out an order or did you simply believe in the revolution and do it because you believed it would contribute to the revolution?
I believed in the revolution and I also carried out the orders which were given to me.
Mr Martin, according to the records, I'll try to get the precise page, the age of the child is given as 13, do you have problems with that?

And I should also mention to you that according to the expert evidence given to the Court, this child was shot at a very close range and also that he had, apart from the fact - as I've already said, half his head was blown away or blown off, he had several other shot wounds.
I cannot answer to the other wounds but I know he was shot with a shotgun.  They were close to him, they were not far from him, maximum of about two metres.
That can hardly be an accidental shooting.
I did not say it was an accident.

Yes.  Let us adjourn until 2 o'clock, I'm sorry I didn't realise that we are well beyond 1 o'clock.  We will start at 2 o'clock.

You were at the same level?

To shave your hair, to take your moustache off?

Miss van der Walt, are we taking this as Exhibit A?
I would appreciate it as Exhibit A.

"Fase een"
and then:

is admitted as Exhibit A, thank you.

Thank you.

At that stage some bombs exploded on the West Rand and in Pretoria itself and there was always something happening and therefore I believed this was part of the revolution.
So it did continue?  It is not that it would continue but it did continue, bombs exploded in Pretoria and on the West Rand?
And this was under the command of Japie Oelofse?

And the vehicles, I don't know if it's quite clear but at the scene after the incident occurred, you have testified that somebody shouted: "There's a car approaching" and the vehicle disappeared, what did you do after you heard that a vehicle was approaching?

I could see that a vehicle was not approaching.  The road was open, I could see there was no vehicle approaching.  The Nissan Sentra of Andre Venter was used to transport these people but we stayed behind with the Mercedes at the scene.
Is it at that stage when you picked up the shells?
You did not leave the scene and come back, you did it at the same stage?

The order as you interpreted it, it was put to you that: "What would have happened with the bodies if hundreds of people were shot dead", how did you interpret the order when it was said to you that there should be bodies?

As I understood him, the Randfontein Commando, our Commando, we should attack a specified target which was the ANC/SACP Alliance and from there onwards we should leave.  It was just one blow and then leave, we shouldn't move around.
And this order for this particular evening, you had to set up a roadblock, identify a target, kill these persons and then fall back?
That's correct, that's how I understood it.
Your relationship with Commander Kloppers socially, do you have the same respect or did you show the same respect to him that you showed him as your commander?
Yes, there was a measure of respect but not such as when we operated in the hierarchy.
Did you look up to him still?

NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MS VAN DER WALT
You referred us to page 12 of Exhibit A, do you remember you are the one who drew our attention to that?  What point did you want to make there?

Yes, but what point did you want to make there?
MR MARTIN
"The following phase, actions of guerilla fighters simultaneously would be through sabotage, strikes and to put the government of the day into chaos"
Isn't this a discussion document, you know which the author discusses various methods that can be used to get power and then for example, through revolution?
That's correct, that's how I see this document.
I think you produced this document when I asked you questions about the policy of the AWB.  Now, did the AWB then at some point adopt this as it's policy?
This is phase one over which we had to write exams.  All the officers involved already wrote this exam and they knew the contents of it.

Yes, but I'm sure if you read books Mausetung you'll still find these theories about revolution, how it can be carried out and the like and I think the author of this book is expressing his views as to how power can be grabbed in a State, how you can stage a revolution or whatever, which is not what I'm asking.  What I'm asking is, did the AWB adopt as it's policy the killing of people for the purpose of achieving ...[intervention]
What I can answer is that the whole phase was adopted as part of exams.  I would then say yes, it was the AWB's policy.

I don't know whether you would know that but even members of the security branch when they are trained, they receive lectures to be told how terrorism is launched and all that kind of thing, they are told as a teaching material.  Is this not a teaching material, a reading material or is this the policy of the AWB?

As I've told you, I believe it's definitely the police because it was written by the General and it was adopted and everybody writes about it.  And what I want to say is, the evening it mentioned to us it was revolution, in other words everybody knew what was written in paragraph 3.  I then see that this would be adopted by the AWB as policy.

Was that done?  Did you ever attend a meeting where the AWB - I'm asking you these questions because you are not the first member of AWB to apply for amnesty and I want to know from you whether it is your evidence that the AWB - I mean, I know, we know that they would issue militant statements that if the time comes they would be prepared to, if the time comes, they would if the need be, resort to whatever actions.  Now, I'm asking you, did the AWB at some point sit down and say: "Now the time has arrived, we are now resorting to military struggle"?

All that I know of is that before this incident with us occurred, that we had several discussions with amongst others, General Oelofse, and it was always revolutionary talk and we all wrote this exam, we knew what the revolution was about.

But this is the material, I'm talking about the material, I understand what you are saying.  Possibly at meetings they said: "If the need arises, we will go over to the military struggle" and at any point, was such a resolution taken?
In my opinion it was taken yes, it was adopted.  This whole phase was incorporated so I am of the opinion yes, definitely it would be the policy of the AWB.
Is that the reason why you think so or that you say so?
You say that because this document - this appears in this document?
And that the officers had to write an exam about it, yes.

Chairperson, if I could just ask here, this document was not dated but if we look at the contents of it, it should be around '85 at the latest because it refers to the President's attempts with the National Council and the UDF's activity.  It's not a new document, it's a document from round about '85.
It's possible, I cannot five you a definite answer to that.
When did you see this document for the first time?
And you refer to 3(c), tell us how does this act that you apply for amnesty for, how does this fall under (c), under which parts, under which words? ...[Transcriber's own translation]
The fact that it says that simultaneously there should be sabotage, assassinations, strikes, so that social chaos and political chaos could be established.
So this falls under etc?  ...[Transcriber's own translation]
Yes, I would say that, yes.
So you base your case on the word: "etc" under 3(c) of this whole document?
To put the government into political chaos, yes.
